comment.author: 64555638@N00
comment._content: I've a photo of the front of the GPO, taken from over near those trams. Probably taken by my great-grandfather who who had an office in Anglesea Street.

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: Nice one [http://www.flickr.com/photos/64555638@N00] that is a great memory to have and thank you for sharing it.

comment.author: 61286047@N00
comment._content: And fifty years later Horatius was to go.

comment.author: 12742105@N00
comment._content: Ohmigoodness..what an amazing shot.

comment.author: 40160780@N02
comment._content: So glad I discovered this site. It's really interesting .

comment.author: 65361386@N05
comment._content: One of the interesting things about this shot is that you can just make out the fallen flagpole from which the "Irish Republic" flag flew - it's on the near top corner of the GPO. (I posted the same comment about a previous pic, but the pole is more obvious here.)

comment.author: 65361386@N05
comment._content: Definitely late May - ie, after the 17th. See Westropp's sequence of pics of demolition of the building in the foreground (Metropole Hotel) on the RIA's site: discovery.dho.ie/index.php#%7B%22fq%22%3A%22(UI_dc_subject%3A%5C%22Easter%20Rising%201916%5C%22)%22%7D

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/65361386@N05] Oh, pefect! Thanks - great to have that confirmation. And you're right, the flagpole is so much clearer in this one...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] Ha! I was wondering if you'd remember that balcony shot. And we decided in the end, with guliolopez's help that they were perched on the rebuilt Metropole...
